nodes.bodyText: This is a respawn and makes sense to not do anything with the logic here.

Once the server can run, I can figure out if we'll need to send fake respawn packets or not (to clear Vanilla client chunk caches).
May need to keep in mind, if not, will need to call the packet hook for this.

I wonder if we need to run this if the type is NETHER and not Vanilla's NETHER.
It may only be used for the dimension triggers which we wouldn't then, been a while since I read up on this.
Where is spawnPortal being fed from?
Forge - it's to allow mod ITeleporters to prevent the creation of an end platforms.

I heavily debated running this for Vanilla's END or END dimension types (since they will use the END generator).
The problem is the Vanilla code, no matter what, puts the platform there. Someone could get angry in a custom end having a build at  spawn get overwrote due to this. For Vanilla END, we can state that is game mechanics.
Should run this after instance check (589)

Here is the big difference between my version of this and yours.
In my version, I run reposition logic by finding where the portal will put you but I don't place any portal blocks. If the event succeeds, I run the logic again based on the event's position and put the blocks there. I did this to prevent cancelling reposition would end up having to roll back blocks in the PhaseTracker.
Basically I run it in the lamdba which, truthfully, was a giant giant pain...

This is the big problem I have.
For vanilla, that's okay. We can do some magic with getExitPortal (or just copy/modify a redirection of it), and that's what my one of my TODOs is about. So if this is a route we wanted to go down, I would have spent some time doing that for vanilla logic - this wouldn't remain here if vanilla logic is running.
For Forge, there's very little we can do because there's no way to feed in the requested position to the mod.
You are correct, in my version if a mod passed in their own lambda we would call no events. It was definitely a flaw but I accepted it cause the whole thing is asinine to begin with.............
This should only be called if it is actually a portal else API usages of NetherPortalType will have the swoosh sound which would be odd imo.
Assuming this code is copied to a util method for handling post teleport logic.
If it is effectively an overwrite, make it one. With auditing, these overwrites like up like a Christmas tree, ensures we don't overlook it.
So if we keep the strategy of doing reposition like this, we need to rollback the portal blocks in the PhaseTracker, issue a ticket for the chunk pos the player is going to, and call moveTo instead.
